windows.name: Install Node.js
description:
What is Node.js?

Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine that includes the npm package manager.

Installation

Download Node.js and install it.

You must restart Wakanda Studio after completing this step.

windows.name: Install Angular CLI
description:
What is Angular CLI?

Angular CLI is a command line utility that allows you to add components, directives pipes, services ..., in addition it allows serving and building your application

Installation

To install Angular CLI, use the Node Package Manager (npm) that is provided by Node.js:

  1. Open the Terminal (start -> run: cmd.exe).
  2. Run this command:
    npm install -g @angular/cli

windows.name: End
description:
Additional Information

If you have any further questions, please contact us at support@wakanda.io.

mac.name: Install Node.js
description:
What is Node.js?

Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine that includes the npm package manager.

Installation

Download Node.js and install it.

You must restart Wakanda Studio after completing this step.
You installed Node.js, but Wakanda Studio has not found it? Solve this issue

mac.name: Install Angular CLI
description:
What is Angular CLI?

Angular CLI is a command line utility that allows you to add components, directives pipes, services ..., in addition it allows serving and building your application

Installation

To install Angular CLI, use the Node Package Manager (npm) that is provided by Node.js:

  1. Open the Terminal.
  2. Run this command:
    npm install -g @angular/cli

NOTE: If NPM command returns an error, run: 

sudo npm install -g @angular/cli

mac.name: End
description:
Additional Information

If you have any further questions, please contact us at support@wakanda.io.

issues.title: Wakanda Studio has not detected my dependencies (node, npm, ionic, ...)
description:
Solution

Wakanda Studio looks for your dependencies in your operating system's default folder. If you installed NPM, Node, or other software in a custom location, add the binary folder location in your Wakanda configuration:

  1. Open Wakanda Studio's Preferences.
  2. In the General panel, go to the Environment variables section.
  3. Insert the binary locations (without the binary name at the end) separated by a new line in the PATH field:
    /my/custom/path/one
/my/custom/path/two
  4. Click on the Check button to check the dependencies in the Console.

issues.title: While running my application I could not log-in inside Wakanda Studio
description:
Solution

If are able to log-in on a browser but you have troubles inside Wakanda Studio, try clicking these URLs (1) and (2) and then try re-opening all the application tabs.

issues.title: The platform I'm looking for is not listed.
description:
We support only iOS and Android for native mobile app development. For other platforms, like Windows Phone, you can create a web application with Wakanda and AngularJS.

Please contact us at support@wakanda.io and let us know which platform you need. We'll send you an email as soon an update is available.

issues.title: npm returns a red error that starts with 'npm ERR! Error: EACCES...'.
description:
Solution

This error is due to insufficient user permissions. If you are on Windows run the command prompt as an administrator. On MacOS run the same command in the terminal prefixed by 'sudo'.

Example for MacOS

Instead of

npm install -g ionic

try

sudo npm install -g ionic

issues.title: npm returns a red error that starts with 'npm ERR! network connect ETIMEDOUT...'.
description:
Solution

In most cases, you might be behind a proxy or have bad network settings.
If you are behind a proxy, please make sure that the npm 'proxy' config is set properly.

Example

In the command prompt/terminal run

npm config set proxy http://proxy.company.com:8080
npm config set https-proxy http://proxy.company.com:8080

If you are working behind a proxy in a "windows" domain, add the domain name into the proxy url:

npm config set proxy http://domain%5Cuser:password@proxy.company.com:8080
npm config set https-proxy http://domain%5Cuser:password@proxy.company.com:8080

You need to encode the backslash as an http uri string: %5C

Additional Information

It could also be necessary to point the npm registry to the http source:

npm config set registry "http://registry.npmjs.org"
npm config set strict-ssl false
